name: Loss Aversion
bias: People feel losses much more strongly than gains, which often leads to overly cautious or irrational decisions.

name: Confirmation Bias
bias: We favor information that confirms our existing beliefs and dismiss evidence that challenges them.

name: Anchoring Effect
bias: The first number we see becomes a reference point and strongly influences later decisions.

name: Availability Heuristic
bias: Events that are easier to remember feel more likely, even if they are statistically rare.

name: Overconfidence Bias
bias: People consistently overestimate their knowledge, skills, and ability to predict outcomes.

name: Status Quo Bias
bias: We prefer things to stay the same, even when change would clearly be beneficial.

name: Herd Behavior
bias: Individuals often follow the crowd instead of making independent decisions.

name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
bias: Past investments of time or money influence decisions, even when they shouldn’t.

name: Framing Effect
bias: The way information is presented changes how we interpret and react to it.

name: Recency Bias
bias: Recent events are given more weight than older, equally relevant information.

name: Survivorship Bias
bias: We focus on success stories and ignore the many failures that never get attention.

name: Endowment Effect
bias: People value things more simply because they own them.

name: Self-Serving Bias
bias: Success is attributed to skill, while failure is blamed on external factors.

name: Optimism Bias
bias: We believe bad things are less likely to happen to us than to others.

name: Negativity Bias
bias: Negative experiences have a stronger psychological impact than positive ones.

name: Hindsight Bias
bias: After an event occurs, we believe it was predictable all along.

name: Illusion of Control
bias: People overestimate their influence over outcomes that are mostly random.

name: Authority Bias
bias: Opinions from perceived authorities are trusted more, even when flawed.

name: Bandwagon Effect
bias: The popularity of an idea increases its perceived validity.

name: Mental Accounting
bias: Money is treated differently depending on its source or intended use.

name: FOMO (Fear of Missing Out)
bias: The fear of missing opportunities leads to impulsive decisions.

name: Present Bias
bias: Immediate rewards are preferred over larger future benefits.

name: Planning Fallacy
bias: We underestimate how long tasks and projects will actually take.

name: Halo Effect
bias: A positive impression in one area influences judgments in unrelated areas.

name: Choice Overload
bias: Too many options make decisions harder and reduce satisfaction.

name: Dunning–Kruger Effect
bias: People with low ability tend to overestimate their competence.

name: Loss Framing
bias: Decisions change when outcomes are framed as losses instead of gains.

name: Gambler’s Fallacy
bias: Past random events are believed to affect future random outcomes.

name: Base Rate Neglect
bias: Statistical probabilities are ignored in favor of specific anecdotes.

name: Scarcity Bias
bias: Limited availability increases perceived value.

name: Availability Cascade
bias: Repeated exposure to an idea makes it seem more true.

name: Social Proof
bias: People assume actions are correct if others are doing them.

name: Regret Aversion
bias: Fear of regret leads to inaction or overly safe choices.

name: Time Inconsistency
bias: Preferences change over time, leading to inconsistent decisions.

name: Outcome Bias
bias: Decisions are judged by results, not by the quality of the decision process.

name: Information Bias
bias: More information is sought even when it doesn’t improve decisions.

name: Normalcy Bias
bias: People underestimate the likelihood of extreme or disruptive events.

name: Emotional Reasoning
bias: Feelings are mistaken for facts.

name: False Consensus Effect
bias: We overestimate how much others agree with our views.

name: Illusion of Transparency
bias: People believe their thoughts and intentions are more obvious than they are.

name: Effort Justification
bias: Greater effort leads to higher perceived value.

name: Probability Neglect
bias: Emotional reactions outweigh actual probability estimates.

name: Anchoring to Past Prices
bias: Previous prices influence how current prices are judged.

name: Peak-End Rule
bias: Experiences are remembered based on their peak and ending, not the average.

name: Omission Bias
bias: Harm caused by inaction feels less serious than harm caused by action.

name: Familiarity Bias
bias: Familiar options are preferred over better but unfamiliar alternatives.

name: Mere Exposure Effect
bias: Repeated exposure increases liking, even without new information.

name: Zero-Risk Bias
bias: People prefer eliminating a small risk entirely over reducing a larger risk.

name: Availability Bias
bias: Easily recalled examples dominate judgment.

name: Default Effect
bias: Pre-set options are chosen more often than alternatives.

name: Risk Compensation
bias: People take more risks when they feel protected.

name: Narrative Fallacy
bias: We prefer coherent stories over complex realities.

name: Ambiguity Aversion
bias: Options with unknown probabilities are avoided.

name: End-of-History Illusion
bias: People believe they won’t change much in the future.

name: Cognitive Dissonance
bias: Conflicting beliefs create discomfort, leading to rationalization.

name: Moral Licensing
bias: Good actions justify later questionable behavior.

name: Overreaction Bias
bias: Recent news causes excessive shifts in beliefs or behavior.

name: Underreaction Bias
bias: People are slow to adjust beliefs to new information.

name: False Causality
bias: Correlation is mistaken for causation.

name: Egocentric Bias
bias: We rely too heavily on our own perspective.

name: Hot-Hand Fallacy
bias: Success is believed to increase the chance of continued success.

name: Loss Attention Bias
bias: Losses capture more attention than gains.

name: Projection Bias
bias: We assume others think and feel the same way we do.

name: Focusing Illusion
bias: We overestimate the importance of one factor when making decisions.

name: Belief Perseverance
bias: Beliefs persist even after evidence is disproven.

name: Affect Heuristic
bias: Emotions heavily influence risk and reward assessments.

name: Scope Insensitivity
bias: People don’t proportionally value larger benefits.

name: Optimism in Forecasting
bias: Future outcomes are predicted too positively.

name: Effort Heuristic
bias: More effort is assumed to mean higher quality.

name: Exponential Growth Bias
bias: People underestimate exponential change.

name: Pseudo-Certainty Effect
bias: Certain outcomes are preferred over probable ones, even if worse.

name: Loss Chasing
bias: People take bigger risks to recover losses.

name: Price-Quality Heuristic
bias: Higher prices are assumed to mean better quality.

name: Selective Perception
bias: We notice information that fits expectations.

name: Emotional Contagion
bias: Emotions spread through groups and influence decisions.

name: Temporal Discounting
bias: Future rewards lose value compared to immediate ones.

name: Identity Bias
bias: Information is accepted or rejected based on group identity.

name: Myside Bias
bias: Arguments supporting our side are judged as stronger.

name: Law of Small Numbers
bias: Small samples are assumed to represent the whole population.

name: Rationalization Bias
bias: Decisions are justified after the fact.

name: Choice-Supportive Bias
bias: We remember chosen options as better than they were.

name: False Uniqueness Effect
bias: People believe they are more unique than they are.

name: Contrast Effect
bias: Comparisons distort perception of value.

name: Anchored Expectations
bias: Initial expectations influence final satisfaction.

name: Risk Aversion
bias: People prefer certainty over uncertainty, even at a cost.

name: Groupthink
bias: Desire for harmony suppresses dissenting opinions.

name: Escalation of Commitment
bias: People double down on failing decisions.

name: Salience Bias
bias: Striking information dominates decision-making.

name: Moral Hazard
bias: Protection from risk encourages riskier behavior.

name: Feedback Loop Bias
bias: Early outcomes influence future behavior disproportionately.

name: Anchoring on Forecasts
bias: Initial predictions shape later estimates.

name: Information Overload
bias: Too much data reduces decision quality.

name: Illusion of Skill
bias: Random success is mistaken for competence.

name: Loss Sensitivity
bias: Small losses feel disproportionately painful.

name: Default Trust Bias
bias: We assume systems or authorities are correct by default.

name: Comparative Neglect
bias: Relative differences matter more than absolute ones.

name: Short-Termism
bias: Immediate results are prioritized over long-term value.

name: Overprecision
bias: People are too confident in exact estimates.

name: Expectation Bias
bias: Expectations influence actual experiences.

name: Status Bias
bias: High-status individuals are believed more readily.

name: Naïve Realism
bias: We believe we see the world objectively and assume others who disagree are uninformed or biased.

name: Belief Bias
bias: Arguments that align with existing beliefs are judged as more logical.

name: Attribution Error
bias: We attribute others’ behavior to character, but our own to circumstances.

name: Just-World Hypothesis
bias: People assume outcomes are fair and that individuals get what they deserve.

name: Ingroup Bias
bias: We favor people who belong to our own group over outsiders.

name: Outgroup Homogeneity Bias
bias: Members of other groups are perceived as more similar than they really are.

name: Reactance
bias: When freedom feels threatened, people resist and do the opposite.

name: Placebo Effect
bias: Belief in an outcome can influence real performance or perception.

name: Nocebo Effect
bias: Negative expectations cause worse outcomes, even without real cause.

name: Escapism Bias
bias: People avoid unpleasant information by disengaging from decisions.

name: Loss Normalization Bias
bias: Repeated losses start to feel acceptable and are underestimated.

name: Novelty Bias
bias: New ideas are overvalued simply because they are new.

name: Tradition Bias
bias: Old practices are favored simply because they’ve existed longer.

name: Action Bias
bias: People prefer doing something over doing nothing, even when inaction is better.

name: Inaction Inertia
bias: Missing a good opportunity reduces motivation to act on later ones.

name: Empathy Gap
bias: We underestimate how emotions affect behavior in different states.

name: System Justification Bias
bias: Existing systems are defended even when they are unfair.

name: Value Attribution Bias
bias: Success is attributed to talent, failure to external obstacles.

name: Pseudo-Expert Bias
bias: Confident speakers are mistaken for experts.

name: Crisis Bias
bias: Rare dramatic events receive more attention than persistent issues.

name: Single-Cause Fallacy
bias: Complex outcomes are explained by one simple cause.

name: Moral Framing Bias
bias: Information framed morally feels more compelling than factual framing.

name: Wishful Thinking
bias: Desired outcomes are believed more likely than they are.

name: Neglect of Opportunity Cost
bias: Alternatives forgone are ignored when making decisions.

name: Self-Consistency Bias
bias: People resist changing opinions to appear consistent.

name: Evaluation Bias
bias: Metrics influence behavior more than actual goals.

name: Efficiency Bias
bias: Efficient solutions are preferred even if they reduce quality.

name: Overgeneralization Bias
bias: Limited experiences are applied too broadly.

name: Reputation Bias
bias: Well-known names receive more trust regardless of merit.

name: Time Compression Bias
bias: Past events feel more recent than they are.

name: Effort Avoidance Bias
bias: Low-effort options are chosen over better but demanding ones.

name: Information Avoidance
bias: People avoid data that could force uncomfortable decisions.

name: Optimism in Risk Taking
bias: Personal risk is underestimated compared to others’.

name: Cultural Bias
bias: Judgments are shaped by cultural norms rather than evidence.

name: Comparative Optimism
bias: People believe they are less at risk than the average person.

name: Outcome Substitution
bias: Hard questions are replaced with easier ones unconsciously.

name: Decision Fatigue
bias: Decision quality declines after making many choices.

name: Repetition Bias
bias: Repeated statements feel more truthful.

name: Attention Bias
bias: What we focus on seems more important than it is.

name: Instrument Bias
bias: Preferred tools shape how problems are defined.

name: Fear-Based Bias
bias: Fear distorts probability and risk assessment.

name: Greed Bias
bias: Potential gains are overweighted relative to risks.

name: Local Maximum Bias
bias: Short-term optimization prevents better long-term outcomes.

name: Outcome Dependency Bias
bias: Past success locks people into specific strategies.

name: Self-Handicapping Bias
bias: Obstacles are created to protect self-image from failure.

name: Reverse Halo Effect
bias: One negative trait overshadows positive qualities.

name: Comparative Bias
bias: Value is judged only in comparison to nearby options.

name: Urgency Bias
bias: Urgent tasks crowd out important but non-urgent ones.

name: Control Premium Bias
bias: People overpay to feel in control.

name: Stability Illusion
bias: Current conditions are assumed to persist longer than they do.
